headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the AT&T Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And I would like now to turn the conference over to our host, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations for AT&T,
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the AT&T Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And I would like now to turn the conference over to our host, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations for AT&T, Mr. Mike Viola. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lori. Good afternoon, everybody. Welcome to our fourth quarter conference call. It's great to have you with us today. Like Lori said, I'm Mike Viola, Head of Investor Relations for AT&T. Joining me on the call today is Randall Stephenson, AT&T'
componenttext:
Thank you, Lori. Good afternoon, everybody. Welcome to our fourth quarter conference call. It's great to have you with us today. Like Lori said, I'm Mike Viola, Head of Investor Relations for AT&T. Joining me on the call today is Randall Stephenson, AT&T's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Stephens, AT&T's Chief Financial Officer. 
Randall will provide some opening comments and then close with 2015 guidance. John will cover our results, and then we'll follow with the Q&A. Let remind you, our earnings material is available on the Investor Relations page of the AT&T website.
I need to call your attention to our safe harbor statement before we begin. It says that some of our comments today may be forward-looking. As such, they are subject to risks and uncertainties. Actual results may differ materially and additional information is available on our Forms 8-K, other SEC filings and on the Investor Relations page of AT&T's website. 
Also want to remind you that we're still in a quiet period for FCC Spectrum Auction 97 or the AWS-3 auction, so we cannot address any questions about Spectrum today. So with that overview, I'll now turn the call over to AT&T's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Randall Stephenson. Randall?

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Mike, thanks, and good afternoon. We're all fighting cold around here. Lorie may end up having to handle this call for us. Before John takes you through the results, I want to take just a couple of minutes and frame where we are.2012 to 2014 was r
componenttext:
Okay, Mike, thanks, and good afternoon. We're all fighting cold around here. Lorie may end up having to handle this call for us. Before John takes you through the results, I want to take just a couple of minutes and frame where we are.
2012 to 2014 was really a period of unprecedented investment for AT&T and for the industry for that matter. And during this period, we built our LTE network to cover more than 300 million people. We expanded our U-verse broadband footprint of 57 million customer locations, and we deployed 5 [ph] of 725,000 business locations. And at the same time, we reengineered our mobile network, and we now deliver the strongest LTE signal in the U.S. 
Now at the same time, we've been aggressively repositioning our wireless customer base. We're giving our customers now a choice of moving away from heavy handset subsidies in exchange for lower monthly prices. And as a result, our customer satisfaction continues to climb and defections continue to fall. And you can see that by our record low annual postpaid churn rate. 
And we also delivered our best ever full year adjusted EBITDA service margins. We've also made a significant investment to migrate our wireline customer basis to the new platforms. At the end of 2014, 76% of our broadband customers were on our fastest IP-based platforms. And our strategic IP-based business services now represent a $10 billion annualized revenue stream and is growing 14% when you adjust it for the Connecticut sale.
And that brings us to 2015. Because with these foundational investments largely behind us and several strategic investments announced to date, the groundwork is now being laid for 2015 and beyond. And today, our customers are expecting us to deliver video across all of our platforms, whether it's traditionally linear video or over the top on U-verse broadband or video to mobile device. So we've been assembling the pieces that we need to do exactly that. 
DIRECTV quickly and significantly shores up the economics of our U-verse video product, and it brings us to the best content relationships in the industry. Our fixed broadband footprint will likely begin expanding to 70 million customer locations in the U.S. when we complete the DIRECTV transaction. And in the Cricket acquisition, it's proven to be a cost-effective way to strengthen our Spectrum portfolio, which is a prerequisite for being in the mobile video delivery business. 
We also laid the groundwork for expanding these capabilities outside the U.S. We've always believed that demand for the mobile Internet and economic benefits experience in the U.S. would be repeated throughout the world. So with that, we've been looking for opportunities to gain a wireless foothold in key markets for the regulatory, and the investment climate is right.
In Iusacell and Nextel International Mexico assets give us of this opportunity. The changes in the Mexican legal and regulatory framework make it attractive for a new to invest. And we closed on Iusacell. And then once we complete Nextel, we'll have a very deep Spectrum portfolio. And this is the first element needed for a robust mobile Internet offering.
We will now have the ability to extend our U.S. network directly into Mexico, building one seamless network expanding 400 million people. And whether it's cross-border businesses, Latino customers of either Cricket or AT&T or Mexican consumers, we will be the only company with mobile Internet capability spanning both countries. And don't forget, DIRECTV brings the premier TV video business in Latin America. So the byproduct of this is represented on Slide 5.
And you go 12 months from now, AT&T's revenue mix is going to look very different. It will be much more diversified. The way we integrate our products and services will be different. And when we end 2015, post DIRECTV, our revenues will come from 4 areas. Our largest will be Business Solutions, that includes both fixed and wireless services and is growing nicely. 
In fact, in the fourth quarter, that's -- that area is growing nearly 6%. The next area will be our consumer TV and broadband business. Then third will be our Consumer Mobility business. Then, obviously, our Latin American businesses with satellite TV and in the Mexican mobility businesses will be our fastest-growing area. And we like this mix a lot. And by the end of the year, we're going to be uniquely positioned in a world of high-speed conductivity dominated by video and it's going to be a very different business.
So with that, I'm going to turn it over to you, John, to go through 2014.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Randall. Hello, everyone. Let me start with our consolidated financial summary, which is on Slide 6.We finished the year strong with solid revenue and EPS growth in the fourth quarter. Consolidated revenues grew to more than $34 billion, up 4
componenttext:
Thank you, Randall. Hello, everyone. Let me start with our consolidated financial summary, which is on Slide 6.
We finished the year strong with solid revenue and EPS growth in the fourth quarter. Consolidated revenues grew to more than $34 billion, up 4.5% when you adjust for the sale of our Connecticut properties. This was driven by strong wireless growth, as we continue to reposition our business model and adjusted revenue growth in wireline, thanks to gains in strategic business services and U-verse.
For the full year, we saw adjusted consolidated revenue growth by more than 3%. This helped drive strong EPS growth. Reported EPS for the quarter was a loss of $0.77. However, when you exclude the significant items we disclosed in the last weeks, earnings per share was $0.55. That's up nearly 4% from a year ago. And if you consider that last year included about $0.02 of equity income from our divested América Móvil interest, that percentage would have been closer to 8%. Adjusted EPS was up slightly for the year even after a success impact from the sale of our América Móvil investment.
These adjustments include although $0.94 of noncash pressure from the year-end mark-to-market charge for our benefit plans. This was almost the reverse of last year when we had a strong mark-to-market gain. The actuarial loss was largely driven by a decrease of a discount rate, but was partially offset by strong performance of our benefit plan investments.
We also had a $0.25 noncash pressure from the write-off of certain network assets, which we told you about earlier this month. And we had $0.13 of cost associated with wireless integration, DIRECTV transaction costs and a loss of the sale of the Connecticut properties.
Now let's turn to our operational highlights starting with Wireless on Slide 7. Before I get to the quarter, it's important to take a look back at the full year and see how far we've come with repositioning our wireless business.
It's been almost a year since we first introduced our Mobile Share value plans and began to accelerate the move of our smartphone base off the subsidy model to AT&T Next. Since that time, the results have been dramatic.
First, we had nearly 3.3 million postpaid net adds, thanks to strong growth of phones and tablets. That's our best full year gain in 5 years. And this includes more than 700,000 postpaid phone net adds during the year. 
These postpaid gains, along with an end of your surge of connected device subscribers, thanks mainly to the Connected Car, helped drive 5.6 million total net adds, our strongest growth in 3 years. Just as impressive, we added nearly 5 million new smartphone subscribers during the year. These high-volume, high-quality customers have an ARPU of about twice that of non-smartphone subscribers.
At the same time, we had our best ever full year postpaid churn. That's a remarkable achievement any time, but even more so when you consider the intense competitive environment we face during the year.
We also had our best ever full year adjusted EBITDA service margins. We achieved that even with record full year smartphone sales. This is the impact of AT&T Next. Already, more than a quarter of our postpaid smartphone base are on equipment installment plans and more than half of our smartphone base has moved off the subsidy model pricing. These are the long-term results we have talked with you about throughout 2014. A repositioning of the smartphone base is working with nearly 70% of our postpaid base now on Mobile Share plans. Now let's look at fourth quarter results, starting on Slide 8.
Let's begin with net adds, where we had another strong quarter. We added nearly 2 million total subscribers, led by postpaid and connected devices. We added more than 850,000 postpaid subscribers, thanks to strong growth of tablets. These tablet gains more than offset a slight decline of feature phones subscribers. But we also grew high quality postpaid smartphone base by another million in the quarter. This includes upgrades and migrations, which we don't include in our net add number.
Connected devices also continued their strong growth as the Internet of Things begins to evolve. Nearly 1.3 million connected devices were added in the quarter, including 800,000 Connected Cars.
Prepaid total loss in the fourth quarter. However, the Cricket brand is showing momentum with positive net adds after losing customers in the preacquisition year ago fourth quarter. The Cricket integration is going strong, distribution has been expanded, churn is improving, and now nearly 3/4 of the customer base has transitioned to the AT&T network.
The fourth quarter is traditionally a strong sales quarter, and you see that in our results. We had record smartphone postpaid gross adds and upgrades with more than 10 million smartphones sold in the quarter. That includes record total upgrades, those customers choosing to stay with AT&T and commits to new device plans. Our upgrade rate exceeded 11% in the quarter.
Smartphones were 94% of all postpaid phone sales, another record for us in the quarter. As expected, postpaid churn was up in the quarter. The fourth quarter traditionally sees increased levels of churn for all carriers. And when you add in the intense competitive activity in the quarter, it's no surprise to see churn at these levels. 
But even with all these noise in the market, postpaid churn levels were comparable to 2 years ago, the last time when fully refreshed iPhone hit the market. And this was of the first time that all major carriers were able to sell that phone during the busy fourth quarter.
Now let's look at revenue gains on Slide 9. Total Wireless revenues grew nearly 8%, as the revenue mix shift we have seen throughout the year continue to play out in the fourth quarter. Equipment revenue growth cap [ph] 70% was strong AT&T Next sales. Service revenues were pressured, as customers continue to shine up for Mobile Share value plans and move away from the traditional subsidy model. We now have more than 18 million smart Mobile Share accounts covering nearly 70% of our postpaid subscribers. And about 58% of our postpaid smartphone base is on no subsidy pricing. 
Mobile Share customers continue to buy up to larger buckets of data. Half of our accounts are on the plans of 10 gigabits or larger. That compares to 27% a year ago. And we're seeing a move to even bigger, larger data plans. Nearly 27% are on plans of 15 gigs or more. That's 3x more than a year ago. This helped drive an 18% increase in data billings.
The take rate for AT&T Next increased to 58% in the fourth quarter or about 5.9 million new Next customers. This impacted cash flows, but we consider this an investment in a great customer base that we are more than willing to make.
We also had about 400,000 customers bring their own devices onto our network. The Next take rate was a step up from prior quarters. While we continue to see strong customer response in our company owned stores and agents with the Next take rate of about 90% of upgrades, the take rate for Next to our other retailers was much less. The strong holiday sales played a role here. 
We typically have a higher percentage of our sales with other retailers in the fourth quarter. These stores are still becoming familiar with Next plans and our sales show that. Plus, with a rush of the holiday season, sales personalities to retailers don't always have the time to take the steps necessary to close the Next transaction. We'll continue to work with these stores and expect the take rate of those locations to pick up in the future.
As expected, the strong Next take rate helped drive the second consecutive quarter of sequential ARPU growth when you factor in Next Billings. When you added Next billings, you get a more accurate idea of what an average customer pays us every month. That average monthly Next billings were up about $28 per month even with the introduction of the Next 24 months long.
As of the Next base growth, so that's the impact of billings, nearly 27% of our smartphone base is now on AT&T Next. Now let's move to our wireline operations on Slide 10.
The transformation of our wireline networks to IP technology has helped drive year-over-year wireline revenue growth. We say it again, this helped drive year-over-year wireline revenue growth when you adjust for the sale of our Connecticut operation. We're really seeing the overall revenue impact of the strategic business services and U-verse. 
Total adjusted U-verse revenues increased by more than 20% and are now about 2/3 of consumer revenues. And strategic business service revenues grew by more than 14% and are now 30% of total Wireline business revenues. Growth was even stronger when you're just out the impact of foreign exchange.
Overall, adjusted wireline consumer revenue increased 2.4%. Adjusted Wireline business revenues were down 1.8%. However, if you adjust for the effective discontinued global hubbing businesses and foreign exchange, that decline would have been just about 0.5%. 
We're still dealing with the impacts of an uneven economy, but enterprise revenues were up slightly. However, the lack of new business formations continue to pressure small businesses. Wholesale also saw pressure in the quarter in part due to our focus on profitable sales. These results help drive a sequential improvement in Wireline margins, which were up 120 basis points over the third quarter of 2014. That's a reversal of trends in recent years when we are seeing sequential declines between the third and fourth quarter. 
U-verse subscribers also grew in the quarter. We added more than 400,000 high-speed broadband subscribers and now added 2.1 million for the full year. We finished the year with 12.2 million high-speed broadband subscribers or more than 3/4 of a broadband base. The transformation to IP broadband is a remarkable accomplishment for our entire Wireline team.
U-verse TV subscribers net adds came in at 73,000. Net adds were impacted by a strategic move to improve the profitability of our Wireline Consumer business. With our high content cost, we targeted profitable, long-term value subscribers with lower churn rates while still taking market share. Now let's take a look at margins on Slide 11. Let's start with our Wireless margins.
Wireless margins were pressured by strong smartphone gross adds and upgrades, investment-related expenses and wireless integration cost. We mentioned earlier that we had our best ever full year adjusted service margins even with record sales, thanks to AT&T Next. We will also see the impact of Next on our quarterly results. 
While our wireless EBITDA service margin was down slightly when compared to a year ago, the fourth quarter of 2014 saw 2.6 million more smartphone sales than in the previous year. And if you compare the results to 2 years ago, when smartphone sales were comparable, the service margins improved over 700 basis points.
Wireline margins improved from a year ago. Wireline margins usually were flat or down between the third and fourth quarter, but that trend changed last quarter. There was pressure from investment expenses and content cost, but this was offset by growth in wireline revenues and solid execution on cost initiatives.
For the quarter, our adjusted consolidated margins were 14.2%, compared to 15.5% in the year ago quarter and just under 13% 2 years ago. Strong smartphone sales also pressured consolidated margins, but our continued efforts for cost efficiency helped to offset some of that pressure.
Now let's move to cash flow. That summary is on Slide 12. For 2014, cash from operations totaled $31.3 billion and $5.7 billion for the quarter. Capital expenditures were $21.4 billion and $4.4 billion for the quarter, and free cash flow before dividends was $9.9 billion and $1.3 billion for the quarter. Free cash flow was impacted by the nearly 6 million AT&T Next sales in the fourth quarter. We pay upfront for those devices while our customers pay us back over time. The record upgrades and strong iPhone sales and the higher sales price mix made an impact as well. This speaks to our willingness to invest in our premium smartphone customer base. We aren't going to turn away good business to manage to a cash flow number. We have the financial strength to finance devices for our best customers, we have the lowest churn and higher ARPU, and that is our focus.
At the same time, our Next receivables significantly increased while our bad debt ratios stayed at traditionally low levels. These are high-quality receivables. We did monetize $1.2 billion of the Next receivables in the quarter as there continues to be great interest from financial institutions. And we do expect future sales of those receivables.
Also, in the fourth quarter, we sold our Connecticut wireline operations to Frontier for $2 billion. Our asset sales strengthen our balance sheet and cash position. In fact, we had more than $10 billion in cash and short-term investments on hand at the end of 2014. We have more than $3 billion in combined free cash flow and asset sales during the fourth quarter with $18 billion for the full year.
In terms of uses of cash, dividends totaled $9.6 billion for the year. And we continue to have one of the strongest yields around. We also announced the dividend increase last month. This is the 31st consecutive year that we have increased the dividend. That puts us on a small select group of companies. That should give you a good idea of how we look at our dividend, say the dividend is important is an under statement. Consider very important aspect of our shareholder return and are committed to it.
At the same time, we maintain the best credit ratings in the industry. Net debt to adjusted EBITDA was at 1.75. And as we told you at the end of last year, the company will continue to focus on maintaining a strong balance sheet, but expects that with pending investments, in the near term, we may go over our 1.8x net debt-to-EBITDA target. Also, as we've told you earlier, after we closed the DIRECTV transaction, our focus with free cash flow after dividends will be on paying down debt.
Let's now look at the fourth quarter and at 2014. I would now like to turn it back to Randall to talk about our 2015 outlook.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, John. We're going to provide more definitive 2015 guidance after we close the DIRECTV transaction, and we do expect that to happen in the first half of this year. But let me frame for you what you can expect from us this year. And I'm going
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, John. We're going to provide more definitive 2015 guidance after we close the DIRECTV transaction, and we do expect that to happen in the first half of this year. But let me frame for you what you can expect from us this year. And I'm going to start by talking about AT&T on a standalone basis, that is before our Mexico and DIRECTV acquisitions.
What we expect to deliver is continued consolidated revenue growth. Our adjusted EPS growth will be in the low single-digit range. We will have expanding margins, consolidated wireless and wireline margins. We will also have improving free cash flow and improving dividend coverage. And then capital expenditures will be in the $18 billion range, the same as we guided earlier, and that's thanks to the completion of a lot of the Project VIP initiatives.
Now if we include Mexico and DIRECTV, the first thing I want to note is that we now expect to achieve even higher multiyear synergies than we had communicated and anticipated when we announced the DIRECTV deal. And so when you add Mexico and DIRECTV, we anticipate no dilution to our adjusted EPS, meaning, our adjusted EPS growth, including Mexico and DIRECTV, will be in the low single-digit range.
We will exit 2015 a different company. We'll be a company with the ability to deliver video to any device. We'll have unique capability to integrate solutions across a diversified base of customers, geographies and technology platforms that are mobile, fast and highly secure. And we will have a path to profitable TV growth. 
We will have a nice set of growing Latin America business is positioned in video in the mobile tenant. So that's what we're focused for 2015 and beyond. We're very excited about the opportunities that are ahead here for us. 
And so with that, Lori, I think we're ready to take questions.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question from John Hodulik with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question from John Hodulik with UBS.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of strategic questions for Randall, if I could. First, Randall, you've been able to put together a Mexican strategy at a very reasonable cost. Is that always you should expect in terms of Mexico, given the expectation that AMX is going to be spin
componenttext: A couple of strategic questions for Randall, if I could. First, Randall, you've been able to put together a Mexican strategy at a very reasonable cost. Is that always you should expect in terms of Mexico, given the expectation that AMX is going to be spinning off a large piece of their business over the next year or so? And then, if we could expand that, you also have a large footprint now in South America, especially Brazil. What are your thoughts on that market? And then maybe the same for Canada. You talked, at least in the release about a North American calling market. If you could sort of comment on your view on the attractiveness of those markets will be great.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, John. Thanks. I'll start with your question on Mexico. And look, the American Movil asset sale is, in one of those things, floating out there. Nobody really yet knows what that is going to look like. And for us, if we wanted to move into Mexico, the
componenttext: Sure, John. Thanks. I'll start with your question on Mexico. And look, the American Movil asset sale is, in one of those things, floating out there. Nobody really yet knows what that is going to look like. And for us, if we wanted to move into Mexico, there were a couple of really unique opportunities in front of us. And just to try to flush out what we're going to be required to América Móvil to sell their assets seem to be an uncertain process. So we pursued Iusacell. And then with the Nextel Mexico asset, what we have here is a set of assets, a Spectrum portfolio that is really a robust spectrum portfolio, a nice sales site grid that will be a very nice place to start and a nice customer base. And so we have the makings for what we need for a very viable and strong Mexico strategy, whether América Móvil sells assets or not. So that's what we try to do, is to try to do that would get us into Mexico and at us and buy from that would sustain itself, and we like these assets. We think these assets are more than sufficient to compete in Mexico and to go in and compete aggressively and take share. So I feel good about the assets we've got. On South America and Brazil, it's too early to say, John. What we have done there is the best Pay TV business in Latin America. And it's a business that continues to grow. It's got a great brand name down there. DIRECTV has done a very nice job of assembling some nice Spectrum in various Latin American markets, where they are doing a fixed wireless absolution for broadband. So there are a number of markets where they have line of sight and the ability to bundle broadband with the TV product. And their brand is strong enough that where they do that, they have really, really good success. And so we're actually actions to get the transaction closed and leverage those assets in Latin America, and it is, it's a really good product, a really good footprint, a really good brand. So we're excited about getting it. On Canada, I think, right now, we have about as much as we as a company can handle. We're not prepared to start talking about going North of the border right now. We've got a lot to execute on. The DIRECTV, get the deal approved. And then, we've got some serious integration efforts that we need to get busy on. And then, obviously, building out Mexico is going to be a full-court press for the next couple of years. So we've got more than we can chew right -- we've been off more than we can chew right now and you'll us focus on what we've consummated to date.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Mike McCormack with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll go to Mike McCormack with Jefferies.

componenttext: Yes, Randall, I guess, just following on, you started out the conversation with the discussion around revenue diversification. What is your thoughts as you look at the U.S. Wireless landscape into 2015 with respect to how back and I guess with respect to pricing and promotion? From an AT&T sampling, you're share Lowe's, okay. one of subs lower churn was. And then maybe one for John, just think about free cash flow to 2015. If we ex out DIRECTV and the acquisitions, what just frame out the moving parts of visit to give us a little more comfort on the dividend payout and also maybe a comment on whether or not see you used to talked rating agencies about the appetite for how high levers to go.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, Mike. In terms of the Wireless business, when you look at 2014, there are some aggressive pricing in the marketplace. But John, I thought, did a nice job of giving a good basis of compare to 2012. And so fourth quarter of 2012, there were 3 com
componenttext: Okay. Yes, Mike. In terms of the Wireless business, when you look at 2014, there are some aggressive pricing in the marketplace. But John, I thought, did a nice job of giving a good basis of compare to 2012. And so fourth quarter of 2012, there were 3 competitors with an iPhone in the marketplace. That was a last time there was a major iPhone launch. And our churn rate this quarter was very comparable to what it was in 2012. And this quarter, there were everybody and the market had an iPhone. So the churn rates in the fourth quarter, relative to what we've seen in the past, were fairly consistent. When you look at the churn rates for the year in light of what I think was a very robust pricing environment, we had our lowest churn rates ever. Now as we move forward, what we're really going to be focused on is the smartphone base. You're going to see us continue to penetrate our customer base with smartphones. We added a million in the fourth quarter by itself. And you're going to really see us focus more and more intently on the business side of the equation. And you're seeing how we're laying out what our segmentation -- or what our business segments will look like as we move into 2015. And we've had a lot of success really focusing on the business segment with our wireless products and bundling that with the VPN solutions and security solutions. And as I mentioned in the opening, that when you put those 2 areas together, that -- well, not put the 2 together, but when you look at the enterprise business segments, both fixed line and wireless combined, it's growing 5.8% in the fourth quarter. That business segment, that segment of customers churns lower than any other segment of the marketplace. It is price competitive. But it's interesting, when you bundle it with VPN and other products that's, that you have a very, very nice business that grows very nicely. And as John showed, we're expanding margins as well. So we're really focused on the high-end customer base. The area where we're seeing a lot more pressure in the market is in the feature phones. We churn feature phones much higher than our traditional smartphone base. And so that's what Cricket serves the purpose to do is to help us adjust that into the market with a very robust and aggressive prepaid product. And as John pointed out in his comments, Cricket, we're getting through the transition. It is now growing. Our prepaid base is growing. That customer base is obviously a very nice complement to what we're doing in Mexico. We're looking forward to take advantage of the Mexico footprint with Cricket. And as you noticed in the last week, we've announced that free unlimited calling from the U.S. to Mexico. And you'll see more and more of those offers materials going the other rate as we build out the Mexican footprint and the Mexican network.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Mike, this is John. With regard to free cash, let me frame it up this way. As you know, we've announced -- we're committed to do about an $18 billion range for CapEx next year. So that's about a $3.5 billion reduction in CapEx or improvement in free ca
componenttext: So Mike, this is John. With regard to free cash, let me frame it up this way. As you know, we've announced -- we're committed to do about an $18 billion range for CapEx next year. So that's about a $3.5 billion reduction in CapEx or improvement in free cash flow. That's step 1. Step 2 is with all of our free cash flow or with all of our CapEx spending in investment, there comes some trailing expense with a reduction in our CapEx, we'll see a reduction of trailing expense. I don't know if it will help us with margins, but it will also help us with free cash flow. So those are 2 major steps. What [indiscernible] is we have invested significantly in our customer base with regard to Next. High-quality receivables, the banks continue to be interested, but we have a portfolio those that we'll be able to securitized this year, and we'll see some turnaround in payback of cash for those that we haven't securitized. So we're optimistic about that. That will be pressured -- those things will be pressured by the continued success of Next. So we may we reinvest some of those Next dollars that we've got this year. We may reinvest from our customer base. We'll make those judgments as we go. And then we'll see some increase in taxes, but not significant. We will likely see some increases in taxes. With all of that being said, I feel very comfortable about the increasing free cash flow and improving dividend coverage guidance that Randall mentioned. We constantly talk to the credit rating agencies, work with them on our plans and try to be transparent with what we have going on. I would expect will see some -- made some announcements on their own, and I'm sure they will make their decisions as we kind of go through the rest of this year. And the final DTV integration plans that we have, they will come out and make their viewpoints known. But those, I would tell you, those conversations have been productive and constructive, but there will understanding our strategies and our approach.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, I guess, without the crystal ball, thinking about the phone-only ARPU level, is there a level of penetration of the value plans inside your base where we start to see that more stable? I know in the past you talked about paper stability as we go int
componenttext: John, I guess, without the crystal ball, thinking about the phone-only ARPU level, is there a level of penetration of the value plans inside your base where we start to see that more stable? I know in the past you talked about paper stability as we go into '15 on various moving parts. But I guess, just isolation phone-only ARPU, getting a sense on when that might be more stable?

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Mike, as you know, on the phone-only ARPU, when I think about that, I think of phone-only ARPU plus our Next billing. And if you look at that sequentially, they grew. And the difference between the historical service ARPUs and the service ARPUs pl
componenttext: Yes, so Mike, as you know, on the phone-only ARPU, when I think about that, I think of phone-only ARPU plus our Next billing. And if you look at that sequentially, they grew. And the difference between the historical service ARPUs and the service ARPUs plus Next Billings has -- that gap has been closing. You guys can figure out the math. But quite frankly, when you sell almost 6 million phones in the fourth quarter on Next and you start billing those for the entire first quarter and throughout next year on a $20 or $30 a month basis, you can understand our optimism about improving ARPUs as we define those. And remember, we define that way because that is what the customers paying us in cash every month. So we feel real good about where we're going and where the processes. We're not predicting or giving guidance with regard to when ARPU plus Next Billings will be greater than they were in the prior year quarter, but we look forward to getting through this year and continuing the progress especially after having a fourth quarter where the sales seem just did an outstanding job of adding almost 6 million customers to the Next program.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the Next sales go -- in our company owned stores in our authorized agents, great performance more than 80%, nearly 90%, as we mentioned. Great take rates in a busy fourth quarter. Quite frankly, on the large national retailers and the manufacturer
componenttext: Yes. So the Next sales go -- in our company owned stores in our authorized agents, great performance more than 80%, nearly 90%, as we mentioned. Great take rates in a busy fourth quarter. Quite frankly, on the large national retailers and the manufacturer owned retail stores, the take rates were smaller. But in the fourth quarter, they have a lot of activity for us. They sell a lot of our phones. A higher proportion of fourth quarter because the holiday season than any other quarter. So we are optimistic about Next take rates increasing overall through the year. And we are also optimistic about working with financial retailers and the other retailers to provide some additional support on how to sell Next and how it works. So we're still real positive about Next and believe that we'll get the number of customers on the non-subsidy plans in line with the number of customers on Next, plus Bring Your Own Device. So we're really moving dramatically out of the subsidy business. That's a good thing long-term and short-term. With regard to the -- if free cash flow impacts, we'll have the flexibility to monetize. We expect to have the flex with the to continue to monetize large of these audits stations. It's worked a very well. The banks continue to have very much interest. And as we stated before, we want to continue a regular pattern of doing this so that we build the history for this entity to keep us with folks with flexibility and financing going forward. I would suggest to you that the activities we have going on now are not to -- are not intended to be looked at to generate cash flow in and of themselves to pump cash flow in any way, shape, or form. It's really more of a prudent management process throughout the year. We'll have flexibility to push forward or pull back depending upon continued interest rates, continued attractiveness from the business from the banks and so forth. But so far, the process is gone extremely well. We've been very pleased with not only demand, but also the financial terms.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: We continue to be confident this Next take rate is going to be above. As John said, in our retail channel, we're now hitting 90%. It's a learning curve. People are learning how to sell this and the mechanics and the process for doing a handset financing p
componenttext: We continue to be confident this Next take rate is going to be above. As John said, in our retail channel, we're now hitting 90%. It's a learning curve. People are learning how to sell this and the mechanics and the process for doing a handset financing program. We then move into our agent channel, which is a very extensive agent channel. At the beginning, it was not very impressive. And the agent channel is now beginning to perform at levels that look like our retail channel. So then you move into the big box retailers, they will follow a similar curve. And we've come to the holiday season. And Jon mentioned it. And they're pushing vaults. And this takes all of it more time to sell assets that finance rather than just one in a box. And so it's just going to be a learning curve, and we're going to stay patient. But we actually feel very good that the numbers continue to move in a positive direction.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015

componenttext: We go to Simon Flannery with Morgan Stanley.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Randall, you talked a little bit about DIRECTV. Could you just give us a little bit more insight into the deal process, the 180 day those price margins I think you referred to a first half close? So how that's going? And then any updates on the synergies.
componenttext: Randall, you talked a little bit about DIRECTV. Could you just give us a little bit more insight into the deal process, the 180 day those price margins I think you referred to a first half close? So how that's going? And then any updates on the synergies. I think you talked about higher numbers. Is that content synergies? Is that more bundling synergies? Is that something that's going to come in early on versus later? And I think you also talked about video to any device. I know Verizon talked about the top rollout in midyear. So is this something that you're going to have a similar type offering this year? And is it that contingent from the DIRECTV close?

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Simon. First of all, deal process. You nailed, the 180-day clock is running again. But obviously, there is a legal challenge going on between content providers and the FCC. And that's kind of the big unknown in our process right now. We're hopeful th
componenttext: Yes, Simon. First of all, deal process. You nailed, the 180-day clock is running again. But obviously, there is a legal challenge going on between content providers and the FCC. And that's kind of the big unknown in our process right now. We're hopeful that the 2 parties, FCC and the content folks, can get that deal settled in short order. I believe there's a court proceeding that's due here soon that will help determine the pace at which that progresses. But even with that, Simon, we're still fairly confident that this thing gets done first half of the year. And so I can't get a more refined that because of this issue. So this issue will be the only issue because of the delay of the 180-day clock to our knowledge right now. As it relates to the synergies, there's a fairly predictable formula with us when we do these large scale deals. And when we're doing the deals, we tend to be fairly conservative. And we've obviously have begun with the DIRECTV management teams, some parlor discussions and getting to a level of detail that's appropriate within the confines of a DOJ review and so forth. And so we're starting to see details on channels and channel cost and so forth. And as a result, as you start drilling down to it, it's fairly much across the board. We're seeing better opportunities in what we've baked into the original deal economics. And so that's why we're fairly pretty confident that we will exceed the merger synergies that we announced at the time that we did the deal. And across the board, they are looking good. And even revenue synergies. When you have 20 million DIRECTV customers that are very, very high end customers, and seeing what the wireless penetration rate that we have in that customer base, it looks really good, the opportunity to be able to sell mobility to those channels and so forth. So across the board, cost synergies, fee revenue synergies, it's all looking better to what we had anticipated when we announced the deal. And then in terms of video to any device, this is one of the key opportunities that we were pursuing when we did this deal. Our customers are demanding video to be delivered across any device. And so one of the primary objectives we will have coming out of the close of the deal is taking advantage of the content relationships that DIRECTV has in our wireless customer base. We envision customers being able to walk out of our stores with content available to them on devices that they have purchased in our stores. You're familiar with the auditor deal that we have done with the churning group, where we are developing over-the-top content with them taking advantage of ways of delivering that to our customers as well. So it's going to be a multifaceted approach in terms of how we bring video to our customers. But we're looking at multiple channels and channel lineups that we would be able to accommodate into our wireless customers, both tablet, as well as handsets, as well as our broadband customer base, 60 million broadband customers. And so stay tuned, there will be more to come. But this is a high priority for us, is getting the content delivered to the mobile handsets and tablets.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015

componenttextpreview: A couple of follow-up questions, if I could. John, there was an attractive opportunity in Latin America, maybe something sizable like América Movil's expected to be, given your funding requirements over the next few years, do you think a transaction like
componenttext: A couple of follow-up questions, if I could. John, there was an attractive opportunity in Latin America, maybe something sizable like América Movil's expected to be, given your funding requirements over the next few years, do you think a transaction like that, you could do a transaction like that and stay within a comfortable leverage rate? Or should we expect some equity component for a sizable transaction. And then, Randall, part of the strategy of allowing the base to move to new pricing with the help on the churn side and what we saw the benefits of that over the prior 2 quarters, we did see churn return to levels similar to 2 years ago, as you pointed out. Are you comfortable with the current pricing strategy in place right now? And do you think this fourth quarter was more of a onetime-ish in nature? Or should we expect churn to remain at elevated levels as we move throughout 2015?

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Joe, I'll answer John's question in Latin America. The América Móvil thing is just 2 uncertainty even answer a question on. And I will say it again. We've got all we can handle right now in Mexico. And we are going to be focused on getting Nextel I
componenttext:
Yes, Joe, I'll answer John's question in Latin America. The América Móvil thing is just 2 uncertainty even answer a question on. And I will say it again. We've got all we can handle right now in Mexico. And we are going to be focused on getting Nextel International closed, integrating that network, integrating those customer channels, integrating the distribution channels and getting ourselves skilled in Mexico. So anything else is just kind of the speculation. And then, probably as it worth conversation at this point.
In terms of churn, I would tell you, I'm comfortable with the performance we had in the fourth quarter as it relates to churn. And I'll say it again. When you compare it to 2 years ago, which was the last major iPhone launch and only 3 national carriers carrying the iPhone, to have a comparable level of churn with the kind of pricing moves we're seeing in the marketplace versus 2 years ago, I think that's pretty good performance and its performance at for the quarter that we're comfortable with. We are, as I mentioned before, I really focus on that area of customer base of that tends to have lower churn and that is our business customer base and high end consumer customer base, where we are experiencing the churn. As John said in the future phone side of the house, and we will address that with our Cricket platform. And so right now, who can call where pricing goes in this industry. I haven't the slightest idea. It moves. It's very volatile. But right now, we have the value equation we have in the marketplace. We have a customer base that demands reliability, that demands speed and that demands quality. They demand a very sophisticated consumer channel and business channel. We have probably the most sophisticated business channel in the industry for B2B, and we think it's very important. And we think also that, that B2B customer segment is more and more demanding security solutions integrated all the way through the cloud with our NetBond strategy. And that's proving to be a very powerful combination in the marketplace. So that's where you'll see us focused. And like I said, I can't predict where pricing will go.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe first one, just, Randall. Obviously, your kind of used -- have been expressed on this Title II as a way to get to the net neutrality issue. But I guess, from the investment community standpoint, are you of the view that there's going to be really an
componenttext: Maybe first one, just, Randall. Obviously, your kind of used -- have been expressed on this Title II as a way to get to the net neutrality issue. But I guess, from the investment community standpoint, are you of the view that there's going to be really anything different about the business in terms of the business you do or how you do it or the investments you're making kind of on a middle to long-term basis? If you could kind of talk us through the investment side of that equation. And then, John, just a question on the write-down of the Copper plan. Can you talk a little bit about what that was, where it was and kind of what kind of expectations we have for that going forward?

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll do. Let me give Randall a break and I'll take the Copper question first. We went through a study. And in our business, there's a active payers at copper payers that are connected to customers and serving customers. There's spare pairs in our ne
componenttext: Sure, I'll do. Let me give Randall a break and I'll take the Copper question first. We went through a study. And in our business, there's a active payers at copper payers that are connected to customers and serving customers. There's spare pairs in our network. They're available and are in great working condition and available to be used if needed. And there are what we consider it appears or pierced that need significant repair work that are not connected to any customers and need significant repair work investment to make functional. We did a detailed study across our network by our network engineers in conjunction with them, identified mark and made a decision to abandon those ineffective payers or what we would -- with the engineers, we call dead payers. We have plenty of capacity to serve our customers with our active payers and spare payers. So we don't expect any limitations on that. We -- that's how we went through the process. It was a very extensive process. It was a very unusual process to go through. We don't expect any further write-offs like this. We're not aware of any. We just thought it was appropriate to recognize this fact. And anybody in our business have seen the change in our access line customer base over the last 5 or 6 years can understand that we would have payers that will be inactive. And in this case, the ones that were not economical to activate, not to mention the fact, this demand make for us to make that investment up our it's across our traditional wireline footprint.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: My favorite topic, Title II. Look, I'll address it from a couple of perspectives. First, Net neutrality I mean, what this debate started out to be pursuing was how do we protect net neutrality, a neutral Internet? And I would tell you I'm not similar -- I
componenttext: My favorite topic, Title II. Look, I'll address it from a couple of perspectives. First, Net neutrality I mean, what this debate started out to be pursuing was how do we protect net neutrality, a neutral Internet? And I would tell you I'm not similar -- I don't know if anybody in the industry who really argues that we shouldn't have net neutrality. And indeed, the President laid out 4 principles for what that meant. And we look at those 4 principles and said, we're okay with those. Those 4 principles, if what resulted from all of this was the FCC. We're given authority to enforce those 4 principles. It has no bearing or impact on our investment decisions, none whatsoever. What causes us pause is if the way you affect those 4 principles is by categorizing the Internet and wireless services as Title II communication services, that's a different deal, all right? And that's something we have to say, what does that mean? And what are the implications of categorizing these services as Title II services to our industry? And I -- the example I give is we are right now trying to obsolete our old legacy telephone services, moving to IP or to all wireless. And there is a very specific process one has to go through to obsolete those services and replace them with the new advanced services. And we're working through that with the FCC. It's a very collaborative process, it works, but it takes a lot of time to make that happen. And we think that we might be able to get to a point where we can obsolete these services and begin replacing them with the new services by 2020. That's an aggressive timeline. The idea of beginning to put our wireless services and our broadband products under those categories and subjecting ourselves to that kind of regulatory oversight is what causes us pause. And when we say we are pausing investment 'til we understand where this is going, that's what we're referring. Now Chairman Wheeler call find some great is should of categorizing these as Title II, but doesn't cause the industry to slow down, doesn't cause investment cycles to slow down, does not cause innovation cycles to slow down, then it will give us some confidence and relief to continue investing at the same pace we have. But until we kind of have clarity, we're saying we're just on any new investment where we're in a bit of a pause mode. But it's really up in the air right now. There are a lot of ways of getting of what the President has articulated, he wanted to accomplish. One of them is Congress is working on it. And that is that Congress would pass legislation that we give the FCC the authority to enforce the 4 principles that the President articulated were important. That works to us. That puts us very similar to where we are today and probably doesn't change our investment thesis for anything we're trying to do. But these really started, heavy-handed regulations on wireless and broadband, if we go down that path, that's what causes everybody some apprehension and uncertainty and begins to change investment thesis and so forth. So it's up in the air. Right now, which is ashes to see what the FCC comes out and we all begin to see what the formulate our plans.

componenttextpreview: I was wondering if we could chat briefly about your commentary. The post completion of some of your pending acquisitions and some other initiatives that seem to be on the table, the debt coverage ratio they go over that sort of 1.8x level. Could you perha
componenttext: I was wondering if we could chat briefly about your commentary. The post completion of some of your pending acquisitions and some other initiatives that seem to be on the table, the debt coverage ratio they go over that sort of 1.8x level. Could you perhaps give us a sense of where that could go? And perhaps, what is your priority maintaining your near-term credit rating? It sounds like discussions with credit rating agencies has been constructive, was hoping to get some clarification, if possible.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take that. If you look at the DIRECTV transaction based on some of the most recent public financials, you'll know that there's a cash piece of the transaction that would approximate about $15 billion. And I think if you go back to the last quarter [p
componenttext: I'll take that. If you look at the DIRECTV transaction based on some of the most recent public financials, you'll know that there's a cash piece of the transaction that would approximate about $15 billion. And I think if you go back to the last quarter [ph] financial statement, their gross debt level could be at [ph] $18 billion to $20 billion. That would be the debt we'd be adding on, as well as any impacts from closing Nextel and Iusacell as compared to our first quarter. And then we've got some other, as we mentioned, we can't talk about the Spectrum auctions, and so we won't do that. We'll have some impact for matters ongoing that will impact our debt ratings. With regard to that, it is very considerable that's our net debt-to-EBITDA ratio would go above 2. I think that's assumed. And possibly in somewhere between the 2 and 2.5 range, I know it's a wide range, but that's where we feel comfortable right now saying it. Those are the kinds of levels of debt that we would expect that could occur once we close all the transactions. What we would then focus on doing is because we would have accretive free cash flow after the DTV transactions we said before, we would take the excess cash flows after dividends and use that, commit that to paying down debt as quickly as possible. We've suggested that over the kind of the course of the 3-year cycle. That ought to get us back to what is more traditional levels. For us, that's the 1.8x net debt-to-EBITDA. And if you look at our current cost of borrowings, some of our recent transactions, but quite frankly, our entire portfolio today, we have after-tax cost of debt in well below 3%. So it's producing interest expense at a very acceptable level at 1.8. We're just a few years ago where interest rates were higher. You might have gotten a comparable answer with the 1 5 or 1 6 net debt-to-EBITDA. So that's where we're at. We'll let the debt rating agencies deal with it as they see fit. But we're comfortable if where we're going and we understand the implications. The last thing I would tell you, Amir, as we announced lastly, we set up a facility with the collection of banks in 18-month, 3-year 5 year terms for over $11 million. The net after-tax cost of that debt averages less than 1%. And we have been very transparent with our plans and activities such that reasonable people as the banks are in this process are still very interested in providing a significant funding at very attractive rates with an ability for us to prepay it without penalty and ability to leave the, if you will, be facility open until such time as we needed. So we feel real good about where we stand in the crowd market. We'll continue to work on it, but will continue to feel good about where we're at.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: So earlier, Randall was talking about lessons learned as you move up the curve with Next. One of your competitors, T-Mobile, has learned they can change the way they provide credit to their customers. They're placing a high priority now on payment history
componenttext: So earlier, Randall was talking about lessons learned as you move up the curve with Next. One of your competitors, T-Mobile, has learned they can change the way they provide credit to their customers. They're placing a high priority now on payment history than some of the traditional credit metrics. Have you learned the same thing? And is there change in the way that you're extending credit to customers as you up Next?

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think there are lessons learned. I think all of us over the years in this industry know that you know your customers better than anybody else does. And Customers that have been with you for a period of time regardless of what the credit score
componenttext: Yes, I don't think there are lessons learned. I think all of us over the years in this industry know that you know your customers better than anybody else does. And Customers that have been with you for a period of time regardless of what the credit scores are, you tend to treat differently. And we have, for many years, done that, whether it be for fixed line side for broadband, U-verse, customers who pay as well and may have lower credit scores. We have actually gone and extended them services like U-verse, which requires significant upfront to investments and so forth. You do on the business side of the house typically know your customers well. And so you're willing to invest in your customers that you know who may have credit scores that are weaker than what a new customer you'd be willing to do the new customer coming in with a low credit score. So they're not and new games in this business. We've all been playing this credit scoring game for a long time. It's a fairly predictable process. We know our customers well. We know when we treat -- to be credit policy, what to expect and then what time frame to expect bad debt reactions. And it's actually gotten fairly mechanical and arithmetic, to be quite honest so I don't think there's new signs of this.
