componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the AT&T Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I'll now turn the conference over to Senior Vice President, Investor Relations, Mike Viola. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you, Kathy. Good afternoon everyone and welcome to our third quarter conference call. Thank you for joining us today. With me on the call is John Stephens, AT&T's Chief Financial Officer. John will be provide an update with perspective on the
componenttext:
Okay, thank you, Kathy. Good afternoon everyone and welcome to our third quarter conference call. Thank you for joining us today. With me on the call is John Stephens, AT&T's Chief Financial Officer. John will be provide an update with perspective on the quarter, and then we'll follow that with a Q&A session. 
Let me remind you that our earnings material is available on the Investor Relations page of AT&T website, and that's att.com/investor.relations. 
The first line item [ph], I need to call your attention to Safe Harbor statement. Before we begin, as you guys know, it's said that there's -- could be some comments today that might be forward-looking, and as such, are subject to risks and uncertainties. Results may differ materially, and additional information is available on the Investor Relations page of AT&T's website. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to AT&T's Chief Financial Officer, John Stephens, to discuss our financial and operational highlights.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and hello, everyone. Thank you for joining us today and for your interest in AT&T. Before we discuss the quarter, I'd like to take a moment and do a quick reset of what we have put in place at AT&T. With the close of our DTV acquisition, w
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and hello, everyone. Thank you for joining us today and for your interest in AT&T. Before we discuss the quarter, I'd like to take a moment and do a quick reset of what we have put in place at AT&T. 
With the close of our DTV acquisition, we became a unique U.S. competitor. We are the first scaled communications and video provider to offer customers fully integrated nationwide products. Our focus is on profitable growth, and we believe that we have in place the products and the platforms that will enable our success. First, you're probably familiar with our new operating segments, business solutions, entertainment and Internet services, consumer mobility and international. These segments are built on a series of investments that have set the stage for a new kind of company. Our network investments for the last 3 years is unprecedented. At a time when customers value and need connectivity more than ever, our integrated high-speed wireless and wireline IP networks are in place, ready to meet the growing data demand. We invested in a deep spectrum position when you combine the spectrum we bought in the AWS auction, along with the WCS spectrum we already own, we have 40 megahertz of spectrum in the pipeline that we can use to meet growing customer demand. Plus, we've added our spectrum from Leap. This provides an efficient way to meet the increasing demand for mobile data. We're also investing in next-generation software-defined networks. We plan to virtualize and control more than 75% of our network by 2020 using cloud infrastructure and SDN. Behind all this is our focus on profitability. Our improving margins are due in large part to our ability to reduce cost and manage our customer base, including letting our customers manage the smartphone handset cycle. Project agile savings are coming through. Automation and digital first have reduced call volumes by an average of 2 million calls a month. Simplified offers help us well. So do the simple blocking and tackling efforts of expense controls, getting it right the first time and working capital efficiencies. We're all serving smarter and growing revenues with [indiscernible] low margins businesses such as global hubbing. We have seen increasing capital efficiencies, not just with lower trailing operating expense, but also driving lower unit cost as we continue to invest in our world class networks. In effect, we are doing more for less. Our expected cost synergies from DirecTV give us even more runway to reduce costs. We are uniquely positioned as a company. No other company has the assets and capabilities in place that we do. We are confident that our investments have positioned us with a sustainable and efficient long-term leadership position. 
With that as background, let me cover our consolidated financial summary, which is on Slide 4. I'll begin by reminding you that third quarter results include DIRECTV operations since our acquisition as of July 25. These results exclude the first 24 days of DIRECTV operations in July. Our financial results this quarter provide further support that our strategy is on target. Consolidated revenues, margins and adjusted earnings all delivered solid growth in the quarter, and our cash flows were exceptionally strong. In the third quarter, our adjusted EPS was $0.74. That's up nearly 14% over last year's third quarter. This includes adjustments for mostly noncash Cricket network decommissioning and DIRECTV merger-related costs. The strong growth comes even with earnings pressure from our Mexico Wireless operations. Consolidated revenues grew to $39.1 billion. That's up nearly 19% year-over-year, mostly due to our acquisition of DIRECTV, but we grew revenues even if you exclude DIRECTV. And again, this number does not include the first 24 days of DIRECTV revenue as we are reporting under GAAP counting. If you add those revenues to our GAAP number, consolidated revenues for the quarter would have been more than $41.2 billion. Besides DIRECTV, we also had growth from solid gains in our business solutions segments, including strategic business services and data and strong IP data revenue growth in our entertainment and Internet services segment. We also had another strong quarter generating cash. Cash from operating activities for the quarter totaled almost $11 billion, up more than 20% over last year's third quarter, and free cash flow was $5.5 billion. That brought our free cash flow dividend payout ratio to 57% for the year. And when you take a look at the last 2 quarters, you can see that we're delivering the financial results that we expected when we started to transform our business. Combine the second and third quarters and you'll see adjusted EPS up more than 12%, $20 billion of cash from operations and $10 billion of free cash flow and record mobility EBITDA service margins in each quarter. Those are the kind of financial metrics we are shooting for and we firmly believe we are positioned to keep that rolling. 
Now let's take a look at our operational highlights, starting with business solutions on Slide 5. Our business solutions segment includes both wireless and wireline results from our business customers. Mobility is the way business gets done these days and going to market with a total connectivity solution plays to the strengths of our company. We can see the benefits of this approach in this quarter. Business wireless and strategic services revenue growth more than offset declines in legacy wireline products. Wireless revenue growth was driven by gains in both wireless service and equipment revenue. Margins were an even better story. Our focus on profitable revenue growth and cutting costs from the business drove a nearly 300 basis point year-over-year improvement in EBITDA margin. Breaking this segment down further, we saw revenue growth in 3 of our 4 customer categories, enterprise, small business and the public sector. Our business wireline revenues were down due to pressure from legacy services, but we continue to see growth stabilization in our wireline data revenues. Total data revenues grew for the fourth consecutive quarter and now comprise nearly 60% of wireline business revenues. Growth in our most advanced data products is outpacing declines in legacy data services. Strategic business services revenue grew by more than 12% year-over-year. And when you adjust for foreign exchange, growth was even stronger, coming in at more than 15%. We also have improving year-over-year wireline small business trends in the last few quarters, and that continued in the third quarter. Plus, when you include mobility solutions, we actually grew small business revenues. This gives you a better idea of how our business solutions team is competing and winning. 
Mobility is just one advantage we bring to the business market. We continue to drive the fiber deeper into our wireline network. We have deployed fiber to 950,000 new business customer locations. As you can see on our business results, we're just beginning to tap this growth opportunity. Our move to software-defined network architecture is not only allowing us to add compelling new services such as NetBond and Network on Demand, but it's also helping us reduce cycle times and move to a lower-cost capital and operation structure. Network on Demand has been met with strong customer response. The product allows customers to adjust network bandwidth as needed in real time. Today, it's available in more than 170 cities, driving improvement in cycle times, and we've already signed more than 275 customer deals. Business solutions focus is making the Network on Demand, the office mobile and the cloud highly secure. That's how we're running our business and we're excited by the results. 
Now, let me talk about our entertainment and Internet solutions results on Slide 6. This is basically our former consumer wireline business and the DIRECTV U.S. operations. Even though we had DIRECTV only for part of the quarter, the results reflect the growing revenue and increased profitability that we expect to receive. Reported revenue almost doubled year-over-year, and even more dramatic was the improvement in margins. Our EBITDA margins came in at more than 22%. That's up more than 800 basis points year-over-year. Essentially, we have converted our quality video business with limited scale into an industry leader, earning solid margins for our DIRECTV acquisition. And we think there's plenty of room to improve even more with the expected cost synergies from the DTV deal. During the past few weeks, we have reached a multiyear agreement with Viacom for U-verse and DIRECTV subscribers, and we believe we're in a path for the best content pricing going forward. Our approach is to develop a win-win situation for both us and the content providers and encourage them to look at our wireless and broadband assets to widen their distributions. Early results have been promising. We're also seeing some early success on the revenue synergies. For example, we are selling DIRECTV in virtually all our 2,200 company-owned stores. The next step is launching certified dealers and online as well as ramping up sales in our call centers. It's starting to make an impact. DIRECTV net adds picked up shortly after the deal closed and were solid throughout the rest of the quarter. That drove 26,000 satellite [ph] net adds post deal close. We now have more than 25 million video subscribers in the U.S. It's important that we do this right coming out of the gate. We've been holding back much of our cross-selling promotions as we train service reps and technicians for our premium single service experience so we will see the benefit of those strategies impact future quarters. As expected, U.S. video subscribers declined in the quarter. Net adds dropped with fewer promotions and shifting our focus to the lower content cost DIRECTV platform. We added 192,000 IP broadband customers in the quarter as migrations from our DSL base continued to slow. U-verse video losses also put some pressure on broadband numbers due to their high attachment rates, but we are confident we can work through this as our single service experience for broadband and satellite is rolled out. As we said, it's early in our integration of DIRECTV. We don't even have a full quarter of results, yet our integration efforts are on or ahead of targets and early results indicate this deal will prove to be everything we thought it would be and more. 
Now let's move to our mobility results on Slide 7. AT&T Mobility operations are now divided between the business solutions and the customer wireless segment. That information is in the investor briefing and staff profile. For comparison purposes, the company is also providing supplemental information for its total domestic wireless operations. 
Let's start first with the total domestic wireless operations financials. We have a compelling value proposition, great network, superior customer service and fair pricing. All of these sometimes get lost in the competitive noise. Our focus is to bring the best customer experience while increasing profitability and not just chase customer accounts. Our third quarter results drive that point home. We had our highest ever wireless service EBITDA margins at 49.4%. Our consumer mobility business helped drive that service margins of more than 50%. AT&T Next sales are a big part of that success, but we also have been very aggressive in taking costs out of the business and increasing efficiencies in our Cricket operations. Total wireless revenues were flat year-over-year. Lower year-over-year smartphone upgrade volumes impacted equipment revenues and Mobile Share Value plans did the same to service revenues. As expected, with most of the conversion to Mobile Share Value plans behind us, we saw increasing stability with our service revenues, which were essentially flat to the second quarter levels. We also continue to see steady growth of AT&T Next and Mobile Share Value plans. About 2/3 of our postpaid smartphone base is on no subsidy pricing with more than 40% on Next. That gives us substantial opportunity to continue to grow equipment revenue as these customers upgrade their smartphones. For the quarter, nearly 80% of the smartphone sales were on Next or BYOD. We also continue to see growing phone only ARPU plus Next, which increased by nearly 5% year-over-year. We also turned in another strong net add quarter as postpaid tablets, Cricket and the connected car drove our highest net adds in nearly 5 years. Those details are on Slide 8. Total net adds came in at 2.5 million as we continue to see the impact of our Cricket acquisition and connected car strategy. The company added 289,000 postpaid subscribers with about 620,000 tablets and computing devices. We also had a record 1.6 million connected device net adds. Most of these were connected cars where we added about 1 million. Or perhaps the biggest story in the quarter had to be our continued strength in premium prepaid. This has been a remarkable turnaround story for us. We added 466,000 prepaid voice subscribers in the quarter after losing subscribers in the year-ago third quarter. These subscriber gains came from both Cricket and our GoPhone products. We also completed our Cricket network conversion in the quarter. We are seeing Cricket deliver great ARPUs. In fact, the ARPU from Cricket smartphones net adds is nearly $10 more than our postpaid feature phone ARPU losses. We continue to grow our branded smartphone base. We added 1 million in the quarter. Branded voice subscribers were also positive in the quarter. Total churn was down year-over-year, thanks to lower prepaid churn, even with shutting down the Cricket network. Postpaid churn for the quarter was up year-over-year as we focus on higher value subscribers. However, year-to-date postpaid churn is running at 1.06%, just slightly higher than last year's best ever full year churn of 1.04%. 
Here's another way to look at churn. We are adding premium prepaid subscribers whose ARPU is higher and subsidy costs are lower than postpaid feature phone subscribers who have the highest postpaid churn. And our success in the prepaid market is resulting in improvement in total churn. Cricket gives us a quality prepaid offering for the more value conscious customer. Same great network, quality customer service and the flexibility prepaid delivers with subscriber acquisition costs that are much lower than the postpaid voice. 
Now let's look at our international operations. That information is on Slide 9. Our international segment provides wireless services in Mexico and satellite entertainment services in Latin America. Let's start with Mexico. 
We are taking the first steps in our investment cycle in Mexico and pushing hard to replicate the same great 4G LTE network experience there that we have in the United States. So far, we're making great progress. By the end of the third quarter, we've already covered about 29 million people with our 4G LTE network. And as of today, we now cover more than 30 million. This puts us on plan to reach 40 million by the end of the year and provide a high-quality platform to sell on. Mexico's financials reflect our network investment and the work being done to bring and Nextel's operations together. This is the heavy lifting of the wireless business, but we've done it before and we're confident we can do it again successfully. We're also confident that we will grow market share. We have a great leadership team in place and a solid plan, not only we deploy the highest quality network, but deliver a superb customer experience as well. It's a great opportunity and the potential synergies over 400 million pop North American calling area make it even better than we first imagined. Our Latin American DIRECTV operations are showing solid growth on a local currency basis, but foreign exchange rates, including our decision to adapt the [indiscernible] rate in Venezuela are pressuring our results. Revenues, ARPUs and margins are all pressured by FX and subscribers also being hampered by challenging economies in the region. But importantly, our Latin American businesses have cash flows that allow us the opportunity to better position our operations. We'll continue to work through these headwinds and work at operational efficiencies in Latin America. 
Now let's move to consolidated margins on Slide 10. Our focus on profitable growth is clearly seen in our consolidated margins. Adjusted consolidated operating margins came in at 20.3% in the quarter. This was a dramatic improvement over the year-ago third quarter, and adjusted EBITDA margin was nearly 200 basis points higher than a year ago. There were several reasons for this improvement. First, the DIRECTV acquisition increased the profitability of our pay-TV business, but just as important was our focused sales approach in wireless and U-verse video. Project Agile savings also are coming in ahead of plan. Our simplified offers and increased efforts to take care of customers on the first call has produced results. Call volumes of our mobility centers continue to drop down an average of 2 million calls a month when compared to the year-ago third quarter. We also have been highly effective with our cost optimization efforts. That has helped drive down costs for excess and in our supply chain. We're also keeping an eye on the force by many minimizing outsourcing expenses. Overall force has been managed through voluntary retirement programs, normal attritions and normal reductions in operations. Trailing operating expenses from capital investments also were down year-over-year. We also are highly efficient with our capital spending and unit costs are decreasing, essentially doing more for less. All of these adds up, and DIRECTV gives us an update to expand margins. We have our target to get to $2.5 billion or more in savings. We already are realizing some of that in our content and supply relationships. We really like our momentum here, and we are confident we can continue to expand margins and cut costs even with pressure from our international operations. We also believe healthy cash flows are fundamental to our success. 
Let's look at Slide 11 for those details. We continue to execute and deliver strong cash flows. In fact, we are increasing our free cash flow guidance for the year. In the third quarter, cash from operations totaled $10.8 billion. That's our best cash generation in 12 quarters, and we generated $26.7 billion in cash year-to-date. Capital expenditures totaled $5.3 billion, about the same as last year's third quarter. Free cash flow was $5.5 billion and $12.8 billion year-to-date. In terms of uses of cash, dividends totaled $2.4 billion, which gives us a dividend payout ratio of 44% for the quarter and 57% for the full year. Our net debt-to-adjusted-EBITDA ratio was 2.28, which was better than our original expectation. Our focus is on maintaining a strong balance sheet. We paid down more than $5 billion in debt early and we still have more than $6 billion of cash on hand. These strong cash flows are fundamental part of our business. This gives us the financial strength to invest in our business, reduce debt and return substantial value to our shareholders. 
Now let me take a -- now let me close with a quick summary and updated guidance on Slide 12 before we get to your questions. First, let's address guidance. We are increasing our full year EPS outlook to the 2 68 to 2 74 range. We also now expect free cash flow to be in the $15 billion range or better this year. All other full year guidance is reaffirmed. Our focus on profitability is a big reason we're able to do this. In the quarter, we saw growing revenues, expanding margins and double-digit adjusted EPS growth. But just as important is our ability to generate cash from our business. Cash from operations was strong and free cash flow gave us excellent dividend coverage. We are seeing positive signs in our largest segment, business solutions. Customers appreciate our integrated solutions approach and are migrating to our newest software-defined network services. We also saw our highest ever wireless service EBITDA margins with an incredible turnaround story in prepaid unfolding. And we closed the DTV acquisition in the third quarter and integration process is on target and positioned to exceed expectations. This is an exciting time for us we believe we have the pieces in place to redefine our business in our industry. 
With that, I will turn it back to Mike so we can get your questions.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Kathy, so we're ready for the Q&A, and if you can queue up the first question, we'd appreciate it.
componenttext: Okay, Kathy, so we're ready for the Q&A, and if you can queue up the first question, we'd appreciate it.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly. That will come from Rod Rozwadowski from Barclays.
componenttext: Certainly. That will come from Rod Rozwadowski from Barclays.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to touch upon the commentary around cash flow, John, if I may. If we take a look at your raised outlook for the year, it does seem as though there's a little bit of tempering in the cash generation in the fourth quarter. I would love to hear abou
componenttext: I wanted to touch upon the commentary around cash flow, John, if I may. If we take a look at your raised outlook for the year, it does seem as though there's a little bit of tempering in the cash generation in the fourth quarter. I would love to hear about what your spending priorities are, and more specifically, how to think about the longer term cash generation capabilities of the joint entity.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, Amir. A couple of things, one, there's always some seasonality in the fourth quarter with the holiday sales, our wireless business with virtual handsets, and so forth. So there's always some seasonality. As you would find also with -- on our wireli
componenttext: Great, Amir. A couple of things, one, there's always some seasonality in the fourth quarter with the holiday sales, our wireless business with virtual handsets, and so forth. So there's always some seasonality. As you would find also with -- on our wireline large business segment. Also, we generally have larger tax payments at the end of the year than we do early on. So those are the things that are impacting us. But I would tell you, if you do kind of a year-over-year comparison, where we're at and what we're projecting with regard to the $15 billion range or better, I think you'll see that we're continuing to have really good cash flows throughout the rest of this year. Secondly, with regard to future years, we would stand by what we've said earlier, that is that we expect free cash flow to provide us with a dividend payout ratio that's in the 70s. We're not moving away from that. We're not shying away from that at all and expect that to continue to be the case. We're certainly proud of these results and glad that we exceeded what we had promised, but we're going to be careful and prudent and predicting our results as we go forward. But we're really excited about where we stand in the future cash generation of this business.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And if I may follow up here, and thinking about the joint entity moving forward, particularly when it comes to the potential opportunities with positioning the company and targeting sort of your end markets. At your analyst update, you had highlighted tha
componenttext: And if I may follow up here, and thinking about the joint entity moving forward, particularly when it comes to the potential opportunities with positioning the company and targeting sort of your end markets. At your analyst update, you had highlighted that there are areas for potential cross synergies, revenue synergies and opportunities, specifically I'm thinking about the 15 million DIRECTV households that don't have access to AT&T wireless services. I was wondering if you can give us some color in terms of how you plan on going after that opportunity and how we should think about leveraging the breadth of the full portfolio to target sort of the areas where you may have one subscriber on one service and not on the other.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Let me take that quickly. First of all, the first revenue synergy that we've really gone after, and we're seeing good success, and quite frankly, we're very excited about the results. It's in the cross-selling of DIRECTV or the satellite products i
componenttext:
Right. Let me take that quickly. First of all, the first revenue synergy that we've really gone after, and we're seeing good success, and quite frankly, we're very excited about the results. It's in the cross-selling of DIRECTV or the satellite products in our company-owned stores. We have about 2,300 company-owned stores, and virtually all of them are actively selling DIRECTV now. And some of them never sold a video product before. So it was -- we had to do some training and some learning. But what we found is we came through the quarter, we were able to sell more and more out of those stores and we got very optimistic
[Audio Gap] 
service those customers integrated basis and we're moving forward. We're starting to sell that based on the really great news we saw from the retail chain. We're really optimistic about single sales results unfold in the fourth quarter and next year. Last thing is, our service technicians have been installing broadband for us, for U-verse for us, but they ended installing DIRECTV. So we've been putting them to through a training program and we expect the rollout in the fully trained on installing satellite in the home in probably November or so, the early part of November, such that we will then be able to sell a single truck roll installation for broadband and video. We're very excited about that. It'll be a measured approach. We're going to have -- we will have everybody trained on the first day, but we're excited about what that will bring. I think that will bring, not only good performance in the fourth quarter, but quite frankly, really look forward to that kind of performance positive performance and impact next year. So that's kind of the way we're thinking about some of those things, Amir.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from John Hodulik from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is from John Hodulik from UBS.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Pretty focus on the guidance. First of all, John, is it possible for you to give us sort of where we are on a year-to-date basis in terms of the 2 68 to 2 74? And then maybe what's driving the change in terms of -- is it just wireless margins that they we
componenttext: Pretty focus on the guidance. First of all, John, is it possible for you to give us sort of where we are on a year-to-date basis in terms of the 2 68 to 2 74? And then maybe what's driving the change in terms of -- is it just wireless margins that they were definitely ahead of where we were? Or are you realizing synergies faster? Or is there any other moving parts will be great.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're at the 2 09 mark today. And so that was ahead of our prior plans. As you know, the $0.74 was ahead -- was ahead of our most recent plans. That has really been driven by cost efficiency. And it's driven by, I think, savings across the board,
componenttext: Yes, so we're at the 2 09 mark today. And so that was ahead of our prior plans. As you know, the $0.74 was ahead -- was ahead of our most recent plans. That has really been driven by cost efficiency. And it's driven by, I think, savings across the board, whether it's a lower number of calls into the call centers, whether it's really top-notch performance of our digital first initiatives, whether it's the streamlining of our installation process through our -- what we call Project Halo or high automation low overhead process, whether the Software Defined Networks. All of those things just blocking and tackling and taking calls into the call centers and getting answers right the first time. All of those things, all of those things are driving cost savings. And we have seen some better performance. as I mentioned, and our business solutions, our business solutions team is really doing well in a tough economy, particularly in the enterprise and the public sector space, but really well in the small business space, and that gives us optimism. So we mentioned with wireless, you are seeing growth in those -- in that area, but we are seeing the acceptance of our Network on Demand, our NetBond, our Software Defined Networks all moving customers in a positive direction. So it's all of those things giving us optimism for the fourth quarter. With that being said, certainly, wireless and it's performance goes without question that is helping drive earnings performance.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike McCormack from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike McCormack from Jefferies.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, maybe just dig a little bit on the churn commentary. Your thoughts on whether or not we're seeing a spike in involuntary. And then how does that sort of pace out if you look at the future phone subs, are those the ones I'm assuming mostly at risk th
componenttext: John, maybe just dig a little bit on the churn commentary. Your thoughts on whether or not we're seeing a spike in involuntary. And then how does that sort of pace out if you look at the future phone subs, are those the ones I'm assuming mostly at risk there? And then secondly, just on the ARPU side, I know last quarter you benefited from year-over-year easy comps. I'm assuming that as we go into the fourth quarter, we should sort of restart that trajectory and year-over-year declines getting better.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me take that, Mike. On the churn, first and foremost, yes, the feature phone churn is hitting us and having an impact on us, and those are decisions we made not to chase those customers. [indiscernible] work on not only the pricing for those customers
componenttext: Let me take that, Mike. On the churn, first and foremost, yes, the feature phone churn is hitting us and having an impact on us, and those are decisions we made not to chase those customers. [indiscernible] work on not only the pricing for those customers, but both the impact throughout our base. But secondly, we believe that we're picking that up and showing tremendous improvement in the prepaid space with Cricket. So we are seeing total churn come down, which I think is really important. With regards to ARPUs, we did have easier comparison in the second quarter of '15 to second quarter of '14 because of some promotional activities that took place in the second quarter of '14, but we've seen stabilization in our ARPUs and we feel -- and in our total revenues. So we feel optimistic about the business going forward. But once again, we're going to be focus on profitable growth, not just chasing customer accounts or specific targets. We're going to be really focused on just getting most props of the business.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Just a quick follow-up on the churn commentary. Is there anything happening on the involuntary side you're seeing there?

componenttext: No, Mike, I wouldn't turn into that. We haven't seen a significant change. In fact, I'd like to point to your, first off, I wouldn't point that our customer base was, quite frankly, we're very lucky to have the quality customer base we have. We're very fortunate.

componenttext: So first on EPS, should we be thinking for '16 of the mid-single-digit or better off of the 2 71 midpoint? Or should we be thinking about different way given the DTV deal?

componenttext: Yes, Phil, let's have it this way. We're not changing our guidance for '16 going forward. So the mid-single-digit growth rate is still good. [indiscernible] I'm not going to refer to -- it's still good even with this adjusted guidance.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the 2 71 is the right starting point. Thanks. And that on Project Agile, can you give us an update on what sort of an overall cost cutting level is here and how we should think about that pacing in the next few years?
componenttext: So the 2 71 is the right starting point. Thanks. And that on Project Agile, can you give us an update on what sort of an overall cost cutting level is here and how we should think about that pacing in the next few years?

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say this. We're going to expect it to continue growing over the next few years. What we had said originally was that we were going -- we were shooting for $3 billion of cost savings. I would suggest to you that we're probably somewhere between a
componenttext: Well, I'd say this. We're going to expect it to continue growing over the next few years. What we had said originally was that we were going -- we were shooting for $3 billion of cost savings. I would suggest to you that we're probably somewhere between a third and a half of the way there and that we plan to at least get there, get to that total target or exceed it. And then I'd point to the $2.5 billion of targeted DTV merger synergies. And certainly, based on what we know now, we expect to see us get there or exceed those. So those would be the 2 points. I would hope that we could exceed the Project Agile targets based on the progress we've made so far. These efforts do take them and investment. We've been spending that time investment in last couple of years to get here. We are seeing the results payoff. We're going to keep our focus in this direction, but we would hope to be able to exceed it.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Simon Flannery with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We have a question from Simon Flannery with Morgan Stanley.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, can you talk a little bit about the video momentum and you sort of went through some of the channel changes here. You had, on a net basis, you did have subscriber losses, but I think you said before that you're hoping to grow your video subscribers
componenttext: John, can you talk a little bit about the video momentum and you sort of went through some of the channel changes here. You had, on a net basis, you did have subscriber losses, but I think you said before that you're hoping to grow your video subscribers over time. So perhaps you could just take us through the quarter and showed us some good growth ads on the DTV side, what's going on there with the churn and when do you expect to return to positive video adds.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Simon, good question. I think we had a slide on this, but the chart can kind of tell you what's going on. Prior to the deal, there were some real pressure in the video satellite video area. There were some -- performance was less than it had been las
componenttext: Yes, Simon, good question. I think we had a slide on this, but the chart can kind of tell you what's going on. Prior to the deal, there were some real pressure in the video satellite video area. There were some -- performance was less than it had been last year. And as you see coming out, after the merger, after we start rolling out sales on the stores, you could see that we really picked up the trend and we expect that to continue. Secondly, with the rollout this quarter of the, if you will, one truck roll or single service experience where we can install TV and broadband at the same time, we not only expect the satellite-TV to pick up, but we also expect the broadband, IP broadband, to pick up because people buy those things together. And so we're hopeful that we're going to see -- we'll be able to show you some improvements and trend improvements -- continuing off of the third quarter into fourth quarter. We'll make any predictions about specific levels, but we are optimistic of what we've seen so far. We think the trends are headed in the right direction and we think the slide that we put together that shows that differentiation between '14 and '15, that will give you a good insight into that.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess U-verse decline, is that sort of run rate or is that all the gross adds shift into the other, DIRECTV or is that churn issue as well?
componenttext: I guess U-verse decline, is that sort of run rate or is that all the gross adds shift into the other, DIRECTV or is that churn issue as well?

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: U-verse is a couple of things. One, certainly, the low-cost -- the lower-cost platform has been our first choice for net adds. Two, we did -- because of focus on profitability, we really got away from promotional pricing and those customers who were cost
componenttext: U-verse is a couple of things. One, certainly, the low-cost -- the lower-cost platform has been our first choice for net adds. Two, we did -- because of focus on profitability, we really got away from promotional pricing and those customers who were cost sensitive just had a propensity to churn. When you first put those steps in place, we saw a little bit of higher churn in the second quarter. We're seeing a little bit higher in the third quarter because of that disciplined approach. But I would tell you that if -- we still have a solid, very good, very high-quality customer base in U-verse, and we're certainly looking to continue to service -- serve those customers with the best products and services. So I think we're focused on lowering churn and keeping those customers quite satisfied.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from Brett Feldman with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question is from Brett Feldman with Goldman Sachs.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick point of clarification and then a question. You talked about the film -- fulfillment accounting methodologies in the slide. Is that your previous methodology change from August or is it something new?
componenttext: Just a quick point of clarification and then a question. You talked about the film -- fulfillment accounting methodologies in the slide. Is that your previous methodology change from August or is it something new?

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brett, that's the same change. If I could, before you ask your question, let me give you insight on it. On a year-over-year basis, in this quarter, the fulfillment accounting had about a $0.02 impact. That is the differential between applying it to DIRECT
componenttext: Brett, that's the same change. If I could, before you ask your question, let me give you insight on it. On a year-over-year basis, in this quarter, the fulfillment accounting had about a $0.02 impact. That is the differential between applying it to DIRECTV and U-verse this quarter as opposed to just applying it to the U-verse product last third quarter '14. And so that could give us some help. Additionally, in this quarter, I want to point out we had about $0.01 of help from the cap [ph] funding activity that went on and what we applied for. By the same token, we had about $0.01 [indiscernible] pressure from the Mexico operations that we had last year. And when we look at our income tax expense, but for the -- setting aside anything that we traded otherwise, there's about $0.02 of income tax pressure, EPS pressure from income taxes. So when you look at the fulfillment accounting and the other kind of unique items that occurred, they kind of balance off with the [indiscernible] funding and fulfillment accounting generating about $0.03 of benefit in Mexico and the income tax is generating about $0.03 of pressure. So we treated those all as going -- because they're going to be going for, because they were to be continuing, we want to make sure I pointed that out. With that being said, Brett, interrupted you before you got ask your question. I apologize.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And was able to the question yes, we have a lot data points disclosures we have found Mylan today. One of the things we see here video ARPU in we have IP broadband ARPU. Our trends in your new entertainment segment and, I guess, as you think about your st
componenttext: And was able to the question yes, we have a lot data points disclosures we have found Mylan today. One of the things we see here video ARPU in we have IP broadband ARPU. Our trends in your new entertainment segment and, I guess, as you think about your strategy going forward, your bundling strategy, I mean, do you have any guidance you can offer to think about the right way to think of the trajectory of those second quarter items because there's a critical to the revenue outlook of that segment.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, think were going to be looking to continuing to protect and improve on the trends that we are seeing, some growing those ARPUs. But likewise, with these assets that we have in place, I would suggest to you that our ability to capture the market, but
componenttext: Yes, think were going to be looking to continuing to protect and improve on the trends that we are seeing, some growing those ARPUs. But likewise, with these assets that we have in place, I would suggest to you that our ability to capture the market, but we're in a very good position to capture the market. Now that we have video where we have broadband without any video, and now that we have broadband, where DIRECTV had video, but didn't have broadband before. So I want to suggest to you that we're going to look for profitable growth and focus on that, but I do -- but we are excited. We are positive about the fact that in some of those cases, we have some growing ARPUs.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, 2 if I could. Just first, John, a little bit following up on that question. Just in terms of the kind of looking at the new way that AT&T is presenting itself to the marketplace, should we be looking at modeling the wireless business separately i
componenttext: I guess, 2 if I could. Just first, John, a little bit following up on that question. Just in terms of the kind of looking at the new way that AT&T is presenting itself to the marketplace, should we be looking at modeling the wireless business separately in consumers business is giving us kind of 2 very unique pictures of 2 very unique businesses? Or is this really just AT&T Wireless the way it's always been run and we really should be just thinking about dividing it between the 2 pieces? Maybe the first one. The second one is on CapEx. Could you -- so many now new parts of the discontinue kind of give us our CapEx is not being allocated between kind of the Latin America, the Mexico, and then domestic business units and how we should think about all those different pieces trending?

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so a couple of things. One, there for investors and analysts piece, we provided total wireless and then provided the consumer wireless the ability to get to the business wireless. So we try to be very upfront with regard to our financial presentation
componenttext:
Yes, so a couple of things. One, there for investors and analysts piece, we provided total wireless and then provided the consumer wireless the ability to get to the business wireless. So we try to be very upfront with regard to our financial presentation. So hopefully, we've been successful at that, but we try to do that to make sure you had that information. Two, I would suggest to you that if you look at margins and EBITDAs and probabilities are -- they are certainly different, but they're not materially different. They don't significantly skew one way or the other. So I just -- I make that observation for you. With regard to how you model, I leave that to you guys. Finally, I can tell you the way we focus though is what the business relationships were selling and what our consumer relationships were selling, and that's how we focus on it. But I think the information is there to do it either way. I think it's going to be a matter of what you're most comfortable with. As we go forward and we see the platform we built with connected devices, show -- start showing more growth even than it already has, it'll be beneficial for everyone to have this split. 
With regard to CapEx, I'm not going to get into specific dollars on a quarterly basis, but I'll give you these insights. On DTV Latin America, our Latin American properties, I would expect that they will be generally self-sufficient, that the cash flows that they generate will be self-sufficient to cover their CapEx needs. I would suggest to you, if we have customer growth opportunities, we'll be prudent about that to make sure that we don't miss out on good customer. But generally speaking, it's going to be self-sufficient from a cash perspective. On Mexico, I would suggest to you that the $3 billion we announced some months ago with regard to the buildout, it's still a good number. We start on that process. I won't tell you that every POP, every 4G LTE POP cost the same amount to create. Some of the networks were more advanced in so some of the earlier achievement may be at a more efficient cost unit cost. But I would suggest to you the $3 billion is still a good number. And then we'll continue to invest, albeit at a slower rate because we've built the platforms out. We'll continue to invest in fiber, in wireless capacity and in success base capital for satellite video product, much of the same way you would've seen us in the past, taking into account the fact that the ramp-up in CapEx for the IP is now behind us. We've got -- we're 950,000 business customer locations passed with fiber. We committed to a million. We'll get to the million, but that's the only piece that isn't done.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping that we could spend a bit more time talking about churn. It seems as though there are some natural future issues that are there in the postpaid side, anyway, prepaid is here in quite well. Could you help us understand if we should be expectin
componenttext: I was hoping that we could spend a bit more time talking about churn. It seems as though there are some natural future issues that are there in the postpaid side, anyway, prepaid is here in quite well. Could you help us understand if we should be expecting more that across the industry? If this is an AT&T specific items that will stick with us for a few quarters or how should we see that? And then secondly, I'm wondering on the DIRECTV synergies. What might be the first opportunity that you would have to update us on whether you are on or ahead of plans for that $2.5 billion?

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the future phone phenomenon, I would tell you that, yes, our base of feature phones continues to get smaller. So over time, we'll get -- we'll lessen the impact this has on our churn. Secondly, I would leave it, Jeff, I would leave it to you guys to ta
componenttext: On the future phone phenomenon, I would tell you that, yes, our base of feature phones continues to get smaller. So over time, we'll get -- we'll lessen the impact this has on our churn. Secondly, I would leave it, Jeff, I would leave it to you guys to talk about it, to decide whether others in the industry are taking this approach. It appears to us from where we see customers moving around that some of the other carriers are not taking the same approach and they're focused more on customer accounts than they are necessarily on the profitability of the customers, but I think you would be the better judge of figuring that out. And I say that based on the offers I see that we are dealing within the noise on the market. On the $2.5 billion, I think, first and foremost, you'll see it in our results, but with regard to updating you, I think we'll continue to update you on that process like we did -- like we've done today where we've talked about how the retail stores are generating sales, exceeding our expectations, how the single truck roll is going to start rolling out in November, those kinds of things. And I think you'll see us also update you, like we did with the Viacom announcement where we basically said that we're going to get best industry pricing for our platform. And so that would imply that we are getting to and getting to or meeting, exceeding our synergy targets. With regards to specifically reporting on the $2.5 billion number, don't expect to be doing that in this -- the rest of this year or early next year because we are still in the midst of really getting it done, and we're more focused on getting it done than we are on reporting out on what it is.

componenttext: Okay. And then secondly, can you just talk about in wireless how you're thinking about device installments versus the possibility of using leases as an alternative financing mechanism for customers and how you see the environment evolving competitively for your mobile smartphone customers?

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, the question. First and foremost, with regard to installment plan versus the lease, we certainly have the financial capability wherewithal to manage either one, to do either one, and we're open to it. But quite frankly, right now, our customers
componenttext: Yes, Mike, the question. First and foremost, with regard to installment plan versus the lease, we certainly have the financial capability wherewithal to manage either one, to do either one, and we're open to it. But quite frankly, right now, our customers seem quite pleased with the installment program and simply put, they seem to like it because at the end of the term, they own the phone and the phones have continued use and functionality for them and they continue to use that. And to some extent, we're saying that from -- we're seeing side of that from this continued use of Bring Your Own Device activities in our company where people are bringing in devices that they already own and hooking up during network. But from a company perspective, it's more of a decision, and Ralph and Wendler and team follow really closely. It's more about what the customers want. And if we see that the customers are going to want that program, we're certainly consider. We certainly have the capability to do it. But right now, what we believe customer satisfaction comes from that ability to own the phone at the end of that I would term and the feel comfortable about that. And what finally, the difference in price, I don't think is measurable from the least of the depending upon what situation you have, but when you get down to the real cause of it, it seems like it's worth that well for us by doing installment plan.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two if I could. First on wireless, and just following up, broadly, do you see value in actually selling the phone to the customer? In other words, does it matter whether somebody gets an new iPhone from you or gets it from orders from Apple and sits on th
componenttext: Two if I could. First on wireless, and just following up, broadly, do you see value in actually selling the phone to the customer? In other words, does it matter whether somebody gets an new iPhone from you or gets it from orders from Apple and sits on their books? And second, on broadband, a couple of quarters now where you're overall losing customers. Just a little insight on what the trends are in DSL, and particularly, where those losses are coming. Are those people in areas where you don't offer U-verse? Or is it migrate -- conditional migration to U-verse in areas where you operate?

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the value side, the customers, it's more about being able to provide investors the full scope customer experience and take care of all things. That's what we're concerned about. From a perspective of the -- if they buy the phone somewhere else an
componenttext:
Sure. On the value side, the customers, it's more about being able to provide investors the full scope customer experience and take care of all things. That's what we're concerned about. From a perspective of the -- if they buy the phone somewhere else and bring it to us, we're thrilled with serving them that way. We don't have the cost of handling the phone or we don't, quite frankly, can have the cost of financing the phone on the installed plan or through a subsidized program. So we're open to it. Right now, one of the equipment installment program that Apple has, in a sense as a high number of phones through that program, and that's why we love to serve our customers that way and that's how they choose to buy their phones Apple and Apple finance system. That's something we can work with. It's really more about what does the customer wanted and how do we make sure we keep -- we provide choices and services to make it easy for our customers. 
With regard to our broadband trends, and specifically in DSL, the first comment I'd make is over the last few years, the real trend has been the migration from DSL to IP broadband, and it's been something that we've encouraged ourselves and we're beginning to complete that process or near completion where the DSL customers we have left is a much lower percentage than have IP broadband capabilities from us. So we are through that migration process. And then secondly, they don't have television in these areas or I should say, we didn't have a video offering, at least we're generally out of the U-verse footprint. But now we do and now we'll be able to provide them a video offering through DIRECTV, and we are very pleased with that. So we are hopeful that now this nationwide video service will help us improving our overall broadband positioning, but particularly, our U-verse broadband footprint there we had the higher speeds where customers generally buy video and broadband together, we now can sell that together. So that's how we're thinking about that. That's how we look to it. But I tell you, on the consumer side, we're down into the 2 million range on total DSL customers. That's basic number step profile, but I would suggest to you, it has changed dramatically over the course of 4, 5 years where it used to be 90% plus of our broadband base and now it's a much lower percentage. So we've gone through that migration. Not completely, but almost completely.

headline: AT&T, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: With that, I want to thank all of you for being on call today and that just give you a few closing comments before we go. The third quarter clearly delivered on our transformation strategy. You saw double-digit growth on our key financial metrics, inclu
componenttext:
With that, I want to thank all of you for being on call today and that just give you a few closing comments before we go. 
The third quarter clearly delivered on our transformation strategy. You saw double-digit growth on our key financial metrics, including another outstanding free cash flow quarter. Integration of DIRECTV is also on track. We expect to meet or beat our $2.5 billion cost synergy target, and we're just beginning to unleash potential promotional activities to drive bundled sales. You can see our increased confidence in the guidance update where we raised our adjusted EPS and free cash flow expectations for the year. We really believe this is just the beginning. We are positioned as a unique competitor and the first scale communications and video provider to offer fully integrated nationwide products and before the expect to increase our momentum as we go forward. 
Thanks again for being on the call. On your way home tonight, please don't text and drive. Remember, it can wait. And as always, thank you for your interest in AT&T and have a good evening.
